Answer the following questions about the compounds <math alttext="N H 2 C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="N C l 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The Lewis electron-dot diagrams of the two compounds are shown.

(a) Calculate the number of moles of <math alttext="N H 2 C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (molar mass <math alttext="51.48 grams per mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>51.48</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>g/mol</mtext></math>) present in <math alttext="1.0 liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of a solution in which the concentration of <math alttext="N H 2 C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="0.0016 gram per liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0016</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>g/L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) <math alttext="N H 2 C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is highly soluble in water, whereas <math alttext="N C l 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is nearly insoluble. Explain this observation in terms of the types and relative strengths of the intermolecular forces between each of the solutes and water.

(c) The value of <math alttext="delta H naught of vaporization" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>v</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>p</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>z</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>∘</mo></mrow></msubsup></mrow></math> for <math alttext="N C l 3, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="32.9 kilojoules per mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>32.9</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Calculate the amount of energy required to vaporize a <math alttext="15.0 gram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of <math alttext="N C l 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> (molar mass <math alttext="120.36 grams per mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>120.36</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>g/mol</mtext></math>).
